New Records: England became the first team to hold both the ODI and T20 World Cups at the same time.
Key Match Events: Ben Stokes scored an unbeaten 51 to steer England to victory.
Sam Curran took 3-12 in his four overs.
Adil Rashid took 2-22, including a wicket-maiden.
Haris Rauf dismissed Phil Salt and Jos Buttler in quick succession.
Shaheen Afridi took a superb catch to dismiss Harry Brook but injured himself in the process.
Shaheen Shah Afridi dismissed Alex Hales with a beauty in England's first over.
Pre-Game Insights: England and Pakistan both took unchanged teams into the decider after peaking at the right end of the tournament.
Key England fast bowler Mark Wood (hip) and batter Dawid Malan (groin) were again left out after struggling with injury.
Despite a forecast of heavy showers and possible storms, rain did not disrupt the match.
Post-Match Reflections: Jos Buttler expressed immense pride in his team and credited Adil Rashid's wicket maiden as key.
Babar Azam congratulated England and praised his team's performance in the last four matches.
Sam Curran was named player of the tournament and player of the match.
Ben Stokes reflected on the importance of the bowlers' performance in the final.
Alex Hales expressed relief and joy at being part of the winning team after missing the last World Cup triumph.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Predicted rain failed to arrive and interrupt the match as 80,462 fans turned out for the final.
The match was a rematch of the 1992 ODI World Cup final at the same venue.
